evidence_span: The photo-current increased rapidly when an oxidized sample (WE) was illuminated with monochromatic light and it saturated in $2 0 \ \mathsf { s }$ (Fig. 6).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk3
evidence_span: Saturated photo-current $( I _ { \mathrm { p } } )$ of each sample (processed by Sequence A and oxidized in $5 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ steam for $^ { 1 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ ) as a function of applied potential $( U )$ is plotted in Fig. 7.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk3
evidence_span: The linear relationships between photo-current $( I _ { \mathrm { p } } )$ and applied potential $( U )$ can be seen. This indicates that the electronic conduction of the oxides formed on all samples was of the $n$ -type

evidence_span: The pure $\operatorname { Z r } \left( \diamondsuit \right)$ showed the same slope as $Z _ { \Gamma ^ { - } }$ EPY Sn $( \bullet )$ and Zr-Sn-Cr $( \sqsubseteq )$ in spite of the large difference of thickness; this suggests that electrical resistivity was reduced by the penetration of the aqueous solution through the cracks of the oxide.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: Recrystallized microstructures are shown in Fig. 12. In both Zr-Sn-Cr (Fig. 12a) and ZrSn-Ni (Fig. 12b), second-phase particles that dissolved in the matrix in the case of Zr-Sn-Cr or linearly aligned at the subgrain boundary of needlelike structure in the case of ZrSn-Ni, have redistributed at random in recrystallized α-grains and on grain boundaries.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: Recrystallized microstructures are shown in Fig. 12. In both Zr-Sn-Cr (Fig. 12a) and ZrSn-Ni (Fig. 12b), second-phase particles that dissolved in the matrix in the case of Zr-Sn-Cr or linearly aligned at the subgrain boundary of needlelike structure in the case of ZrSn-Ni, have redistributed at random in recrystallized α-grains and on grain boundaries.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: From electron diffraction and EDX analysis, second-phase particles in each alloy processed by Sequence B, (i.e., recrystallized materials) were identified as hexagonal ZrCr₂

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: From electron diffraction and EDX analysis, second-phase particles in each alloy processed by Sequence B, (i.e., recrystallized materials) were identified as tetragonal Zr₂Ni

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: From electron diffraction and EDX analysis, second-phase particles in each alloy processed by Sequence B, (i.e., recrystallized materials) were identified as cubic ZrFe₂

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: The volume fractions and particle sizes drastically decreased by β-quenching.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: The data of volume fractions suggest that supersaturation of Ni occurred by β-quenching even in ZrSn-Ni alloy.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: These data also show that growth of particles and increase of volume fractions occurred in the process of recrystallization (i.e., during the repetition of cold rolling and α- annealing).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: Raman spectra of oxides formed on Zr-Sn and Zr-Sn-X (X: Fe, Cr, or Ni) alloys in 500°C steam are shown in Fig. 16.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: Raman spectra of oxides formed on Zr-Sn and Zr-Sn-X (X: Fe, Cr, or Ni) alloys in 500°C steam are shown in Fig. 16. The oxides formed on Zr-Sn-X (X: Fe, Cr. or Ni) alloys had the peaks of the tetragonal phase (261 and 148 cm⁻¹).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: Raman spectra of oxides formed on Zr-Sn and Zr-Sn-X (X: Fe, Cr, or Ni) alloys in 500°C steam are shown in Fig. 16. The oxides formed on Zr-Sn-X (X: Fe, Cr. or Ni) alloys had the peaks of the tetragonal phase (261 and 148 cm⁻¹).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: Raman spectra of oxides formed on Zr-Sn and Zr-Sn-X (X: Fe, Cr, or Ni) alloys in 500°C steam are shown in Fig. 16. The oxides formed on Zr-Sn-X (X: Fe, Cr. or Ni) alloys had the peaks of the tetragonal phase (261 and 148 cm⁻¹).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: A cubic phase peak (625 cm⁻¹) was detected in Zr-Sn-Fe alloy.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: From Fig. 17, fine grains (~20 nm) of monoclinic ZrO₂ and lattice image could be observed.

evidence_span: The lattice spacings were 5 Å and 3 Å, which agrees well with the spacings of the (100) and (111) planes of monoclinic ZrO₂.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: The lattice spacings were 5 Å and 3 Å, which agrees well with the spacings of the (100) and (111) planes of monoclinic ZrO₂.

value: Zr2Ni less stable than ZrFe and ZrCr

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: Oxide films on zirconium alloys undergo an evolution of their physical properties as they thicken. Initially, on plane surfaces, oxide films less than ~2 μm thick are coherent and essentially free from cracks and pores.

evidence_span: Oxide films on zirconium alloys undergo an evolution of their physical properties as they thicken. Initially, on plane surfaces, oxide films less than ~2 μm thick are coherent and essentially free from cracks and pores.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: Alloying element atoms incorporated into such an oxide at the oxide/metal interface will experience an effective oxygen partial pressure close to the equilibrium for the oxidation reaction at that temperature (~10^-65 atm. at 500°C).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: When the oxide thickness exceeds about 2 to 3 μm, depending upon the oxidation conditions, the oxide become porous and cracked.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: When the oxide thickness exceeds about 2 to 3 μm, depending upon the oxidation conditions, the oxide become porous and cracked.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: In the samples oxidized in 288°C water, effects of alloying elements on the photoelectrochemical characteristics were clearly observed (Fig. 9). In this case. the oxide thickness was less than 1 μm.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: In the samples oxidized in 288°C water, effects of alloying elements on the photoelectrochemical characteristics were clearly observed (Fig. 9). In this case. the oxide thickness was less than 1 μm.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: The matrix composition in one Zircaloy-2 (Zry-2) and four Zircaloy-4 (Zry-4) materials has been measured with the atom probe technique. It was found that only about 10% of the alloying elements Fe, Cr, and Ni added to the alloy remain in solid solution in the matrix of nuclear fuel claddings.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: Even a Zry-4 material analyzed directly after a β quench operation had a matrix concentration of only 0.02 wt% Fe and 0.03 wt% Cr.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: Even a Zry-4 material analyzed directly after a β quench operation had a matrix concentration of only 0.02 wt% Fe and 0.03 wt% Cr.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: Atom probe analysis was also used to study the oxide-metal interface in oxide layers formed in dry air and water on needle shaped Zry-4 specimens. Transmission electron microscopy of the oxide layers showed that these were approximately 10 nm thick and contained 5 nm sized oxide crystallites in an amorphous layer.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: Atom probe analysis was also used to study the oxide-metal interface in oxide layers formed in dry air and water on needle shaped Zry-4 specimens. Transmission electron microscopy of the oxide layers showed that these were approximately 10 nm thick and contained 5 nm sized oxide crystallites in an amorphous layer.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_029_chunk7
evidence_span: According to atom probe analysis, the thin oxide layers had a low oxygen content, less than 50 atomic percent.
